title: Ethereum 2.0 Final Upgrade Complete – Network Processes 100,000 Transactions Per Second
shortdescription: The Merge Part 2 brings instant finality and zero gas fees as ETH price surges 40% overnight.
author: Emma Chen

content.content: Ethereum's long-awaited 2.0 upgrade has reached its final milestone, completing the blockchain's transformation from proof-of-work to a fully scalable proof-of-stake network. The upgrade enables the network to process 100,000 transactions per second — up from 15 TPS — while reducing energy consumption by 99.95%. Gas fees have effectively dropped to near-zero, making Ethereum competitive with centralized payment processors for the first time. The upgrade sent ETH surging 40% to $6,800, its highest price since 2021, as investors celebrated the network's scalability breakthrough. This momentum follows record institutional crypto adoption that brought capital into crypto markets.

The final upgrade, code-named 'The Convergence,' introduces sharding technology that splits the network into 64 parallel chains, each capable of processing transactions independently. This architectural change allows Ethereum to scale horizontally, meaning transaction capacity increases linearly with the number of validators. The network now has 2.4 million active validators, staking a collective $150 billion worth of ETH to secure the blockchain. Ethereum co-founder Vitalik Buterin called it "the most significant technical achievement in blockchain history." This infrastructure supports the growth of tokenized real-world assets and stablecoin ecosystems.

With near-instant transaction finality and zero fees, Ethereum has become viable for enterprise applications that require high throughput. JP Morgan has migrated its JPM Coin stablecoin network to Ethereum 2.0, while Visa has launched a pilot program for cross-border payments. The improved scalability has also unlocked new DeFi possibilities — lending protocols can now process mortgage applications in real-time, and decentralized exchanges handle institutional trading volumes without congestion. Total value locked in Ethereum DeFi has surged to $800 billion, doubling since the upgrade. This aligns with enterprise blockchain adoption and institutional crypto adoption trends.

Ethereum 2.0's success has set a new benchmark for blockchain technology. Competing networks like Solana, Avalanche, and Polygon are under pressure to match Ethereum's combination of security, decentralization, and scalability. However, Ethereum's first-mover advantage in developer adoption and network effects gives it a significant edge. With over 5,000 dApps now running smoothly on the upgraded network, Ethereum has solidified its position as the "world computer" for decentralized applications. Analysts predict ETH could reach $10,000 by mid-2026 as institutional adoption accelerates and the network becomes the infrastructure layer for Web3.
